description: {"blocks":[{"key":"fqd7j","text":"For metabarcoding purpose, the first step involves the amplification by PCR of a given gene region (for example V4 or V9 region of 18S rRNA gene) or gene itself if its size does not exceed 600bp (the highest fragment size that can be sequenced by Illumina technology). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9codt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d24nf","text":"The defined forward and reverse primers that are complementary upstream and downstream of the region of interest, needs to be designed with overhang adapters which will be used in a subsequent limited‐cycle amplification step, in order to add the dual‐index barcodes and Illumina flow cell adapters. To design illumina primers, it will be necessary to know the sequencing method, and therefore the adapters sequence. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4fr13","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fegea","text":"The following protocol explains the generation of 18S-V4 PCR amplicons for eukaryote metabarcoding analyses on sorted cells from seawater samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1d9if","text":"Here we described the amplification protocol for 2 sequencing platforms (Genomer, Roscoff, France \u0026 Get-PlaGE, Toulouse, France).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4734i","text":"Extract DNA/RNA from the samples using the method/kit appropriate to the specific samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7cipv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2qo7l","text":"Filtered environmental samples usually have more DNA than sorted cells samples, so the V4 region of the 18S rRNA gene can be amplified by a single PCR reaction (without the need of a nested protocol).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"djnum","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ar0a","text":"Sorted populations by flow cytometer can be used as an input for the PCR reactions. Photosynthetic pico and nanoeukaryotes populations selected based on light scatter, orange phycoerythrin and red chlorophyll fluorescence are sorted in sterile eppendorf tubes containing Tris-EDTA lysis buffer (Tris 10 mM, EDTA 1 mM and Triton x-100 1.2%).The Tris, EDTA and water use should be molecular grade. A buffer containing Tris-HCl 10 mM, pH 8.0 and NaCl 20 mM and filtered at 0.22 μm should be used as sheath liquid for marine samples. Sheath fluid samples should be collected and analyzed as negative controls in all subsequent steps including sequencing, in order to test for contamination in the flow sorting process. After the sorting, samples can be stored at -80C. The DNA from sorted cells can be extracted by three cycles of freezing in liquid nitrogen and thawing in water.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"r8sv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"anfs8","text":"When working with RNA, another step to transform the RNA in cDNA is necessary. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8jjk7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7qv63","text":"Quantify and quality-check the final DNA via NanoDrop or Qubit/PicoGreen Method.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1intr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"am5k4","text":"The A280/260 ratios should be 1.8 or higher and once working with total community extracted DNAs, a concentration of at least 1 ng/μL is desirable to get consistent PCR results. Avoid secondary extractions or clean-ups for inhibitors, until PCRs have truly shown inhibition (example after trying the PCR by diluting the original DNA and/or adding BSA to the final PCR reaction) – many suboptimal DNAs will still work in PCR. A gel can be run to verify integrity of the extracted material, but it is generally unnecessary for PCR-only studies (Figure 1). Some protocols suggest the normalization of the DNA samples concentration prior to the PCR. In our experience, this is not always possible given the low concentration of some samples. The volume of sample added to the PCR can be settled in function of a range of concentrations instead of normalizing all the samples to the same concentration.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":542,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"45v48","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"efkil","text":"Load in agarose gel 0.8%, 1μl DNA + loading buffer. The limit of DNA detection using EtBr gels is around 10ng.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1ggu4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6d610","text":"  ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"87gkf","text":"Each DNA sample have to be normalized to 5ng/µl for PCR. For that, dilute DNA in nuclease free water.","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1cv2r","text":"It is not necessary to check the DNA concentration after dilution.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"90b8j","text":"Samples with a DNA concentration less than 5ng/µl will be amplified as is in PCR.","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"942uc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"817D6ED9FD7711EABADC0A58A9FEAC2A","height":234,"id":238506,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ba065","text":"Figure 1: DNA/RNA detection in agarose gel.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/public/74c8ab47edabda576cff2a9e74c9a44e54793fe1ada5d629a38e12e2539cda14/cjw8g6iw.png","shadow":true,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/hi7kg6iw.jpg","type":1,"webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/hi7jg6iw.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dkohn","text":"Below is a suggestion of protocols for 18S amplification from sorted cells. This protocol has been tested and used with success.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cn7ag","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3qo8c","text":"However, before starting the library preparation, few samples from the batch (es) to be analyzed should be selected and the PCR conditions should be tested. The tests can be performed by using the primers without the illumina “tail” which are less expensive since it can be order by normal purification method, like Se-POP. By using also these primers, it avoids excessive manipulation of the primers with the illumina tail and therefore the chances of contamination. Low number of cycles, pool multiple (i.e., triplicate) PCRs for each sample, high initial time of denaturation are fundamental practices for the PCR when targeting diversity studies and should be considered for all reactions, including the tests in order to reduce or avoid PCR bias caused by PCR selection and PCR drift.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fr1it","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"80mtu","text":"• PCR  selection includes all mechanisms which inherently favor the amplification of certain templates due to properties of the genes and/or of their flanking sequences of the target region. Potentially important contributors to PCR selection are preferential denaturation due to overall low GC content, higher binding efficiency of GC-rich permutations of degenerate primers, differential accessibility of rRNA genes within genomes, and correlation between amplification probabilities and gene copy numbers within genomes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":2,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c1mat","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3bhkm","text":"• PCR drift is cause by stochastic variation in the early cycles of the reaction (when amplification still proceeds largely from the genomic templates), and its outcome should therefore not be reproducible in replicate PCR amplifications.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":2,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3oceu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5agon","text":"More details about these biases can be found in the following references: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2v4vg","text":"-Aird, D. et al. Analyzing and minimizing PCR amplification bias in Illumina sequencing libraries. Genome Biol. 12, R18 (2011).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6qopv","text":"-Wagner, A. et al. steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"95eje","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dq841","text":"Use the existing primers (Table 1 \u0026 Table 2) or design your own custom gene primers with the proper Illumina indices and Index adaptor orientations. {"blocks":[{"key":"3uqsa","text":"If the PCR’s product are not concentrated enough, you could purifie and concentrate them in a smaller volume using a purification and concentration kit like “Nuclesopin Gel \u0026 Clean up kit– Macherey-Nagel”.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f4516","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79vdk","text":"Once PCR products are correct, they are pooled and organized in appropriated PCR plates to generate libraries.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b8u7e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"70mv4","text":"We use a high throughput sequencing using paired-end 2x300bp Illumina MiSeq with the 600-cycle v3 kit.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2jf8l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"en51m","text":"If the illumina sequencing is realized on the Genomer Platform in Roscoff (France), see the protocols.io \"Preparation of libraries (Metabarcoding) for Illumina sequencing -
